mn22:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn22:2.1: Now at that time a mendicant called Ariṭṭha, who had previously been a vulture trapper, had the following harmful misconception:
mn22:2.2: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
mn22:3.1: They went up to Ariṭṭha and said to him,
mn22:3.2: “Is it really true, Reverend Ariṭṭha, that you have such a harmful misconception:
mn22:3.3: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them’?”
mn22:3.4: “Absolutely, reverends. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
mn22:3.5: Then, wishing to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him,
mn22:3.6: “Don’t say that, Ariṭṭha! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
mn22:3.7: In many ways the Buddha has said that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them.
mn22:3.8: The Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
mn22:3.9: With the similes of a skeleton …
mn22:3.16: a butcher’s knife and chopping board …
mn22:3.18: a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.”
mn22:3.19: But even though the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him in this way, Ariṭṭha obstinately stuck to his misconception and insisted on it.
mn22:3.21: When they weren’t able to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the mendicants went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

mn22:13.5: “Suppose there was a person traveling along the road.
mn22:13.6: They’d see a large deluge, whose near shore was dubious and perilous, while the far shore was a sanctuary free of peril.
mn22:13.7: But there was no ferryboat or bridge for crossing over.
mn22:13.11: ‘Why don’t I gather grass, sticks, branches, and leaves and make a raft? Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I can safely reach the far shore.’
mn22:13.12: And so they’d do exactly that.
mn22:13.13: And when they’d crossed over to the far shore, they’d think,
mn22:13.14: ‘This raft has been very helpful to me.
mn22:13.15: Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I have safely crossed over to the far shore.
mn22:13.16: Why don’t I hoist it on my head or pick it up on my shoulder and go wherever I want?’
mn22:13.18: Would that person be doing what should be done with that raft?”
mn22:13.20: “And what, mendicants, should that person do with the raft?
mn22:13.21: When they’d crossed over they should think,
mn22:13.22: ‘This raft has been very helpful to me. …
mn22:13.24: Why don’t I beach it on dry land or set it adrift on the water and go wherever I want?’
mn22:13.25: That’s what that person should do with the raft.
mn22:13.26: In the same way, I have taught a simile of the teaching as a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on.
mn22:14.1: By understanding the simile of the raft, you will even give up the teachings, let alone what is not the teachings.

mn22:30.1: Such a mendicant is one who is called ‘one who has lifted the cross-bar’, ‘one who has filled in the moat’, ‘one who has pulled up the pillar’, ‘one who is unimpeded’, and also ‘a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached’.
mn22:31.1: And how has a mendicant raised the cross-bar?
mn22:31.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up ignorance, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:31.3: That’s how a mendicant has lifted the cross-bar.
mn22:32.1: And how has a mendicant filled in the moat?
mn22:32.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up transmigrating through births in future lives, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:32.3: That’s how a mendicant has filled in the moat.
mn22:33.1: And how has a mendicant pulled up the pillar?
mn22:33.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:33.3: That’s how a mendicant has pulled up the pillar.
mn22:34.1: And how is a mendicant unimpeded?
mn22:34.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up the five lower fetters, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them, so they’re unable to arise in the future.
mn22:34.3: That’s how a mendicant is unimpeded.
mn22:35.1: And how is a mendicant a noble one with with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached?
mn22:35.2: It’s when a mendicant has given up the conceit ‘I am’, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
mn22:35.3: That’s how a mendicant is a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached.

mn22:42.1: The teaching well-explained thus by me is clarified, revealed, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork.
mn22:42.2: In this teaching thus well-explained, for those mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found. …
mn22:43.2: In this teaching thus well-explained, those mendicants who have given up the five lower fetters are all reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. …
mn22:44.2: In this teaching thus well-explained, those mendicants who, having given up three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion, are all once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. …
mn22:45.2: In this teaching thus well-explained, those mendicants who have ended three fetters are all stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening. …
mn22:46.2: In this teaching thus well-explained, those mendicants who are followers of teachings or followers by faith are all are bound for awakening.
mn22:47.1: The teaching well-explained thus by me is clarified, revealed, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork.
mn22:47.2: In this teaching thus well-explained, those who have a degree of faith and love for me are all bound for heaven.”
